sections.section: Chapter 2: Overview of Data Ecosystem & its Lifecycle

questions.question: What is the definition of a Data Ecosystem according to the text?
options: A collection of databases used by an organization.
A group of people who analyze data for business insights.
A comprehensive suite of integrated tools and technologies for the entire data lifecycle.
The physical infrastructure where data is stored.
A software application for creating data visualizations.

questions.question: The term 'ecosystem' is used because all the components, from data collection to business decisions, are interdependent.
Which of the following are considered key components of a Data Ecosystem? Select all that apply.
_________ store structured, filtered data that has been processed for a specific purpose and is optimized for fast SQL queries.
What is the primary difference between the ETL and ELT approaches to data processing?
options: ETL is faster and more flexible than ELT.
ELT is an older, traditional method.
ETL transforms data before loading it into a warehouse, while ELT transforms it after loading.
ETL only works with structured data, while ELT only works with unstructured data.
There is no significant difference; the terms are interchangeable.

questions.question: According to the text, what is a key characteristic of 'File data sources'?
options: They are labeled by users and stored in the input machine.
They reside within single, shareable files, allowing multiple users to access them.
They require a specific server location and driver engine to be accessed.
They are exclusively used for internal data.

questions.question: Data originating from sources like IoT devices or web scraping tools is known as secondary or processed data.
Which of the following are classifications of data sources mentioned in the text? Select all that apply.
A _________ _________ is a type of software programmed to sift through databases and extract information.
The text uses the analogy of a 'loading dock' to describe data analysis, where insights are shipped out to business users.
Why is data ingestion considered a crucial first step in the data pipeline?
options: It is the only step where data is secured.
It is the most expensive part of the process.
Without it, there is no data to analyze, forming the foundation for all data-driven decisions.
It automatically cleans and transforms all incoming data.
It is where business intelligence reports are generated.

questions.question: Prominent solutions like Flume and _________ _________ are pivotal components of the Hadoop ecosystem that facilitate scalable data intake.
What is the typical latency for Real-Time Data Ingestion?
A use case for real-time data ingestion in e-commerce is generating monthly sales reports.
In real-time ingestion, the data flow is a continuous, _________ stream.
When is batch-based ingestion most advantageous?
options: When an organization needs to gather specific data points daily and does not need real-time data.
When dealing with a continuous, unbounded stream of data.
When processing individual transactions as they occur.
When monitoring live patient data in healthcare.

questions.question: Which of the following are described as Batch Ingestion Patterns by Scheduling Frequency? Select all that apply.
The Incremental Load (Delta) data extraction method is simple but resource-intensive because the entire dataset is replaced each time.
The data extraction method that tracks inserts, updates, and deletes is known as _________ _________ _________.
Which analogy is used to describe Micro-Batching?
options: A freight train (carries everything at once, daily)
A subway system (frequent departures with small groups)
A postal service (delivers mail once a day)

questions.question: Micro-batching offers lower latency than traditional batch processing but higher latency than true real-time processing.
According to the comparison table, which data processing model is best for achieving a balance between freshness and throughput?
options: All models are equal in this regard.
None of the models can balance freshness and throughput.

sections.section: The Complete Process of Data Ingestion

questions.question: In Step 1: Data Collection, which of the following are listed as sources of data? Select all that apply.
Which task in the Data Transformation step involves adding context by merging with other data sources?
Data Lakes are described as a target system for storing structured data for analysis and reporting, like Amazon Redshift or Snowflake.
Which of the following is the first step in the Data Ingestion Workflow?
What are the challenges in data ingestion mentioned in the text? Select all that apply.
The text concludes that data ingestion is a minor step with little impact on an organization's ability to use its data.
The text uses a cooking analogy where raw data is like a final, edible meal and transformed data is like raw ingredients.
What are the key goals of data transformation? Select all that apply.
options: Making data more complex and harder to read

questions.question: Transformations involving basic tasks like cleansing and filtering are considered _________ data transformations.
Converting various state abbreviations like 'NY', 'New York', and 'N.Y.' into a single, consistent format 'New York' is an example of which transformation type?
A major drawback of the traditional ETL process is that the original raw data is often lost after transformation.
In the modern ELT process, where does the data transformation take place?
options: On a staging server before loading
Within the source system before extraction
Within the data warehouse/lake after the raw data has been loaded
It does not require a transformation step

questions.question: According to the comparison table, which approach is fully compatible with data lakes?
The traditional ETL approach is generally more cost-effective than the modern ELT approach because it leverages cloud resources.
Which of the following are listed as applications of data transformation? Select all that apply.

sections.section: Types of Data Ingestion Tools & Data Loading

questions.question: Which type of data ingestion tool is described as a fully managed service where you configure sources and destinations via a UI?
Loading data into real-time processing systems enables sub-second latency for applications requiring instant insights.
Which of the following are real-life uses of real-time data processing? Select all that apply.
The technique of utilizing memory (RAM) to store and process data to reduce delay is called _________-_________ _________.

sections.section: How does Real-Time Data Processing Work?

questions.question: In the real-time data processing workflow, what happens immediately after 'Data ingestion'?
What are the advantages of Real-Time Data Processing? Select all that apply.
One of the disadvantages of real-time processing is its complexity, as designing and managing such systems can be complicated.
Hadoop is a proprietary, closed-source framework that requires expensive, specialized hardware to run.
Which of the following are considered core components of Hadoop? Select all that apply.
All the components of the Hadoop ecosystem revolve around a single core element: _________.
What is the primary goal of HDFS?
options: To provide low-latency data access for transactional systems.
To deliver high throughput for reading and writing large files.
To efficiently store millions of small files.
To manage cluster resources and job scheduling.

questions.question: The 'Write Once, Read Many' (WORM) philosophy means that data in HDFS is frequently modified and updated after being written.
In the HDFS architecture, the _________ is the master daemon that manages the file system namespace and metadata.
What is the role of the DataNode in HDFS?
options: To manage the file system metadata.
To schedule jobs across the cluster.
To store the actual data blocks on local disks.
To perform periodic checkpoints of the NameNode.

sections.section: Key Design Goals & Characteristics of HDFS

questions.question: Which of the following are key characteristics of HDFS? Select all that apply.
HDFS is highly efficient for storing millions of small files because it minimizes metadata overhead on the NameNode.
To provide data durability and fault tolerance, each data block in HDFS is replicated across multiple DataNodes, with a default replication factor of _________.
What is a major weakness of HDFS?
options: It is very expensive to run.
It is inefficient with small files, which can overload the NameNode.
It has poor throughput for large files.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the MapReduce programming model?
options: To store data in a distributed file system.
To provide real-time, low-latency data access.
To make large-scale data processing feasible and fault-tolerant using a 'Divide and Conquer' approach.
To manage and schedule cluster resources.
To provide an SQL-like interface for querying data.

questions.question: The 'Shuffle & Sort' phase in MapReduce is a manual step that requires developers to write complex code for data grouping.
The two main phases of the MapReduce model are the _________ Phase and the _________ Phase.

sections.section: The Complete Data Flow of MapReduce

questions.question: What is the role of the optional 'Combiner' in the MapReduce data flow?
options: It divides the input file into splits.
It writes the final output to HDFS.
It performs local aggregation on the Mapper node to reduce network traffic.
It sorts the data before it reaches the Reducer.
It is another name for the Reduce task.

questions.question: What were the key benefits that made MapReduce revolutionary? Select all that apply.
MapReduce is a foundational technology for the Big Data era, abstracting away the complexity of distributed computing.
Which component of YARN is the master daemon responsible for resource assignment and management across the entire cluster?
A _________ is the fundamental unit of resource allocation in YARN, representing a logical bundle of resources like CPU and RAM on a single node.
The ApplicationMaster is a generic component that manages all types of applications in the same way.
What is the first step in the YARN workflow?
options: The client submits an application to the ResourceManager.
The ApplicationMaster notifies NodeManagers to launch containers.
The ResourceManager allocates a container for the ApplicationMaster.
Application code is executed in containers.

questions.question: Which of the following are listed as features of YARN? Select all that apply.
A key advantage of YARN is its simplicity, as it removes all complexity and configuration overhead from the Hadoop ecosystem.

sections.section: Key Components of the Hadoop Ecosystem

questions.question: Which tool is designed for efficiently transferring bulk data between relational databases and HDFS?
Which of the following tools are categorized under 'Data Warehousing & SQL-on-Hadoop'? Select all that apply.
_________ is a centralized service for maintaining configuration information and providing distributed synchronization, keeping the ecosystem coordinated.
In the restaurant kitchen analogy, what does HDFS represent?
options: The head chef who assigns tasks.
The waitstaff who take customer orders.
The giant, walk-in refrigerator and pantry where ingredients are stored.
The order ticket rail where new orders are placed.
A team of fast, efficient cooks.

questions.question: The Hadoop ecosystem's primary importance is that it transformed Hadoop into a single-purpose batch processing tool.
In the restaurant kitchen analogy, which component is like the head chef who assigns tasks and resources?
